title: Australia's richest person loses bid for rooftop helipad
text:
A﻿ bid by mining magnate Gina Rinehart to construct a rooftop helipad at the Perth headquarters of her company has been rejected by local councillors.

City of Perth councillors backed recommendations from planning officials and voted six to two in opposing the application at a council meeting last night.

Rinehart, the richest person in Australia, had sought to include a helipad designed to hold a Bell 429 helicopter on top of Hancock Prospecting's revamped headquarters in West Perth.

A proposal by mining billionaire Gina Rinehart to build a helipad on her company's revamped Perth headquarters has been rejected by councillors. (Supplied)

Hancock said the helipad would be used only a maximum of 12 times every year.

Noise impact from the helicopter would ﻿be limited to a few minutes during landing and take-off, the company said.

But council planning chiefs decided to oppose the application, arguing noise levels could not be eased and the helipad would impact nearby residential land.

Among the councillors who voted for a motion against the application was Lord Mayor Bruce Reynolds.

He told the meeting that Rinehart was an "amazing Australian", but backed planners' concerns about noise and environmental impacts.

A Hancock Prospecting spokesperson said the outcome of the meeting was disappointing and the company would consider further options.

An artist impression of Hancock Prospecting's revamped headquarters in Perth. (Graphic: Cox Architecture)

They pointed to a telephone poll conducted by the 6PR radio station in Perth last week that showed strong public backing for the helipad proposal.

The spokesperson also ﻿restated the company's stance that public safety would not be impacted and environmental impacts would be kept to a minimum.

"Independent technical assessments confirmed noise would not exceed existing ambient noise levels for the area, in fact, even reaching the highest current ambient noise level would occur for less than one minute per month – and only during daytime hours," they said.

"Other expert technical reports addressing aviation safety and wind downwash confirm the helipad can operate safely and appropriately within the existing and future inner-city context."

The spokesperson said Perth had missed an opportunity to showcase itself as a global mining and business hub, arguing other ﻿international cities had helipads.

"Rooftop helipads are commonplace in major and premier CBDs around the world including New York, London and Tokyo."

title: One-in-five mortgage holders rue taking on huge home loans
text:
H﻿undreds of thousands of Australian mortgage holders think they've borrowed too heavily to finance their home loans, according to new research today.

A survey by comparison site Finder canvassed 1017 people, 297 of whom have a mortgage, and showed one in five think the financial burden is too much.

That is equivalent to 627,000 homeowners across Australia.

H﻿undreds of thousands of Australian mortgage holders think they've borrowed too heavily to finance their home loans, according to new research today. (Dominic Lorrimer)

The findings come after ﻿the Reserve Bank of Australia board decided yesterday to keep interest rates on hold at 3.6 per cent.

While the decision left mortgage holders disappointed, economists and commentators have not ruled out a possible hike in the cash rate next year.

They point to inflation stubbornly remaining outside the RBA's target range as a hurdle to further cuts.﻿

Finder home loans expert Richard Whitten said some borrowers had stretched themselves to enter the housing market.

"Many Aussies who took out a loan at the top of their borrowing capacity are now finding themselves with a mortgage that's pushing their budget to its limits.

"When you layer home loan repayments on top of everything else – groceries, energy bills, insurance and more – the costs quickly add up.

"Homeowners are having to make some tough decisions – cutting back on essentials, dipping into emergency savings, or postponing major life plans just to keep up with their repayments." ﻿

Last month, 37 per cent of homeowners said they struggled to pay their mortgage, according to Finder's Consumer Sentiment Tracker.

Whitten warned if rates increase next year, anyone who's already stretched will feel the pinch immediately.

"Shaving even half a per cent off your interest rate can save you thousands of dollars."

title: 'Shocked to the core': Beloved Christmas tradition scrapped in Sydney
text:
Sydney residents have lashed out at David Jones after its iconic Christmas window display was abruptly scrapped this year.

Hornsby Heights father Phil told radio station 2GB the decision shattered a family tradition he had passed down to his seven-year-old daughter Lucy.

"I went around Elizabeth Street, went around Castlereagh Street, went around Market Street - no Christmas windows," he told 2GB radio host Clinton Maynard.

The Christmas display at David Jones in Sydney CBD in 2021. (SMH)

"What I find shocking is this has been a tradition of David Jones for the last 70 years.﻿

﻿"I was going back through the archives, I found a photo from 1952 of kids gathering around there.

"My mother used to tell me about ﻿my grandfather taking her down when she was a little girl, so this is something that's been going on for so long.

"It's such a tradition and I think it's a real loss for Sydney's Christmas.

"Melbourne's Myer is still running Christmas windows so I'm just shattered we're not doing it here.﻿"

The father said he asked staff and he was told the store wasn't doing the window this year.

﻿"That's a small sentence, but for me it carries a big loss," he said.

"This is about community and sharing the joy of Christmas time that Sydney families have enjoyed for decades."

The department store﻿ told the radio station it has opted to feature its loyalty program mascot Domino the Dalmatian which fits in with its theme, "A very rewarding Christmas".

One caller Denise said she regularly visited the department store to view the Christmas display.

"I was just shocked to the core when I heard about DJs in the city," she said.﻿

"I was that upset ﻿that I went on their website and put a nice review on there for them."

Listener Ros told Maynard she was "disappointed" by the lack of decorations.﻿

"What a load of crap with the Dalmatians, excuse my French," she said.﻿

"﻿We all love Dalmatians but they don't have a lot to do with Christmas, with respect to those wonderful dogs," Maynard said.

Caller Louise said she preferred the Christmas decorations in the Melbourne CBD.

"I try not to be outraged too much," she said.

"My ﻿husband and I were in Melbourne, we were very lucky to watch the Australian Open golf on the weekend, and we went into the Melbourne CBD yesterday and it felt so lovely for Christmas.

"I begrudgingly said to my husband, 'Wow, Melbourne just does it so much better'," she said.﻿

A David Jones spokesperson said the team understood "how deeply sentimental the Christmas windows are for many families and truly appreciated the feedback".

"This year, we're celebrating A Very Rewarding Christmas – a season all about the joy of giving, cherishing moments with loved ones, and enjoying the benefits of our new loyalty program," the spokesperson said.

"To reflect this theme, the Elizabeth Street windows feature Domino the Dalmatian, our symbol of loyalty, brought to life through animation in our campaign.

"While the windows look different, the Christmas magic continues in-store with the Santa Experience, the Christmas Shop, the David Jones Choir, and our Christmas Shopping Festival on 11 December.

"We greatly value our customers' feedback and will carefully consider it as we plan future Christmas experiences."

title: 'The social media ban is the easy option. That's why it will fail'
text:
Opinion: I keep seeing people acting shocked that social media is out of control, and yet the ban feels like the government has finally noticed a problem we've been living with for years and picked the laziest fix.

Being 15 and online isn't easy. I think anyone could tell you that. You're constantly faced with pressure to keep up with trends, look or act a certain way, and stay plugged in. Always.

It's chaotic, exhausting, and most people I know will admit that they're probably better off without it.

Fifteen-year-old Grace Anderson says the Australian government is taking the easy option with the implementation of the social media ban. (Supplied)

Social media hasn't just crept into the modern teenager's lives, it's steamrolled straight through.

But this doesn't mean the blanket ban is the hero solution it's been sold as.

In my opinion, banning social media is punishing the people. The people aren't the problem. The apps are.

'What Australia needs is an overhaul, a genuine effort to collaborate with social media companies on making them a safer and useful place for everyone'

Banning every under 16 doesn't fix the parts of social media that are actually broken. It doesn't change the algorithms that shove extreme content in your face. It doesn't make platforms take responsibility for the way they design apps to keep us addicted.

When someone finds a way around the ban - because trust me, they will - the cycle just repeats.

Nothing improves. The problem doesn't disappear, it just goes into hiding.

Cutting teenagers off such a big part of society for the first 16 years of life doesn't "fix" social media. It just means that when we do turn 16, the shift is an unnecessary confrontation with reality that could so easily be softened.

Policies like these act as if every teenager is the same. That's not true - as if a 12-year-old on TikTok at 2am is identical to a 15-year-old using Instagram to keep up with school, friends, and sport. A harsh rule doesn't recognise differences.

Differences in people, in apps.

I don't want to be treated like one big problem to be managed.

If governments actually wanted to help, they'd go after the companies. Force them to fix features that make social media so damaging - streaks, instant gratification, constant notifications. Instead we're stuck with a ban, which is the most basic solution to this complex problem.

I could've thought of it.

I'm not against it. Not fully. I can see where they were coming from. I see the addiction in society, I see it in myself.

But there were so many ways to help. To help kids see themselves in lights that aren't overshadowed by their phones. What Australia needed right now wasn't an age restriction, a blanket ban, a loss of trust with the government.

What Australia needs is an overhaul, a genuine effort to collaborate with social media companies on making them a safer and useful place for everyone.

They took the easy option, and it will fail.

Do you support banning under 16s from using social media? Yes 10410 No 3458

title: Juggernaut tech giant to launch legal challenge against social ban
text:
What happens when you suddenly kick millions of teens off social media? We're about to find out with the eyes of the world watching.

All sites that meet the government's definition of an age-restricted social media platform must now show they are doing enough to block under-16s from access or face multi-million-dollar fines.

Follow our live coverage and reaction from throughout the day.

Opinion: 'A ban is the easy option, not the hard option, and that's why it will fail'﻿

title: Bull and horses caught wandering into the home of Aussie politician
text:
A politician from the Northern Territory had some surprise visitors in his house after a bull and a horse were caught sneaking in through an open door.

Andrew Mackay, who is a Country Liberal MP for the Northern Territory electorate of Goyder, shared a video of several farm animals gaining access to his home via a backdoor that had been opened by his pet dogs.

The pet camera initially showed two of his dogs pushing the sliding door open with their noses to get outside, leaving it slightly ajar.

Two horses and a bull were seen entering Mackay's house. (Facebook/Andrew Mackay MLA)

Mackay now thinks the animals may be tempted to return. (Facebook/Andrew Mackay MLA)

A large white bull was then seen poking his head through the door, before stepping fully inside the room.

A horse then follows suit, with both animals having a curious wander around what appears to be a living room.

Another horse is also seen on the camera standing outside the door, but it is unclear if they also ventured into the house.

Mackay, who posted the video to his official Facebook account, was able to see the funny side of the situation despite the potential dangers of a bull walking around his home.

"Note to self: The dogs can't be trusted with door security…" the post read.

A somewhat bewildered Mackay surveys the mess made, though none of the animals were harmed. (Facebook/Andrew Mackay MLA)

"Dinner finished early last night when I decided to check the pet cam to find Thunder figured out how to nuzzle open the door."

The end of the video taken later that night shows Mackay surveying the mess the animals made, with one of his dogs beside him.

He said there was no major damage and that all animals in the video were unharmed, but he still had some concerns they may return.

"Now the outside animals know what aircon feels like and will no doubt try again," he said with a hint of humour.

title: The NDIS is introducing computer-generated plans. Here's what that means
text:
﻿Reports of ﻿computer-generated NDIS plans have been circling for weeks, leaving some participants and their families worried.

The new plans appear to be part of cost-cutting efforts at the NDIS, which is projected to cost Australia $52.3 billion in the 2025-26 financial year.

But what is the new ﻿I-CAN assessment tool, how will these computer-generated NDIS plans work, and when will they come into effect?

Here's what we know so far.﻿

The NDIS is introducing computer-generated plans - but that doesn't mean it's using AI. (Getty)

What are NDIS computer-generated plans?

Talk of "computer-generated NDIS plans" refers to the new digital tool the NDIS will soon be implementing to help determine participant funding.

In October, the government announced changes to how budgets are determined for NDIS participants.

Under the new method, budgets will be decided based on a Support Needs Assessment.

The base of the assessment will be formed by the Instrument for the Classification and Assessment of Support Needs (I-CAN) tool.

Developed by ﻿the University of Melbourne and the Centre for Disability Studies, the I-CAN tool has been used in the Australian disability sector for 20 years.

The I-CAN tool is a computer program, but it's not AI.﻿

"The Support Needs Assessment is not automated and does not use artificial intelligence," a National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) spokesperson told 9news.com.au.

"Decisions about a participant's needs will be made by a real person.

"Assessments will be conducted by trained assessors and plans will always be approved by real people who are trained NDIA staff." ﻿

When will the new NDIS computer-generated plans start?

"From mid-2026, the NDIS planning process will begin changing to make it fairer, more consistent and easier for participants," an NDIA spokesperson said.

The I-CAN planning model will be rolled out in stages, according to The Guardian.

The NDIA is reportedly ﻿conducting participant and staff information sessions now.

How does the I-CAN tool calculate my budget?

The I-CAN tool will be used in conjunction with ﻿in-person assessments to produce a Support Needs Assessment and develop participant budgets.

An NDIS participant will first meet with a trained assessor who will work to understand their ﻿life and disability support needs.

The participant can bring family, support people or carers to the meeting.

A new personal and environmental circumstances questionnaire will also be used to collect additional information about the participant's support needs.

In some cases, ﻿where the participant's needs are more complex, reports from their treating health professionals may also be submitted.

﻿Information gathered by the assessor will be checked with the participant and their carers and put into the I-CAN tool.

It will then cost the participant's support needs and provide a budget or funding package.

All budgets produced using the I-CAN﻿ tool must be approved by an NDIS staff member.

However, NDIS staff cannot make any changes to a budget generated by I-CAN, according to reports.

Staff can only request a ﻿new assessment from the I-CAN tool using different inputs.

A ﻿spokesperson for the NDIA, which administers the NDIS, said the new method would ensure more consistent collection of information and inform fairer plan budgets.

"This planning process uses a person-based and strengths-based approach that will result in simpler plans with more flexibility," they said.

"It will also reduce the need for participants to collect and pay for expensive reports."

The spokesperson also said NDIA staff will spend more time with participants under the new framework.

Under the new framework, NDIS staff won't be able to amend budgets produced by the I-CAN tool. (9News)

What if I disagree with my NDIS computer-generated plan?

Participants still have the ﻿right to request a review of their plan, either internally or through the Administrative Review Tribunal (ART).

An internal review may involve conducting another assessment using the I-CAN tool.

If a participant is still unsatisfied, they can request a review through the ART.

However, tribunal members will reportedly no longer have the power to directly amend an NDIS participant's plan if they believe it's incorrect.

More than 7000 new cases of participants appealing NDIA decisions were brought before the ART in the 2024-25 financial year alone.

That figure represented a ﻿76 per cent increase year on year.

title: Minister racks up $1000 bill at the tennis. But it's not against the rules
text:
Anika Wells is under the microscope once again for her taxpayer bills after she spent $1000 on a government-funded car to wait while she watched the tennis.

The frontbencher is already under fire for spending nearly $100,000 on flights to New York, $3000 on a family ski trip and another $4000 on flying her husband to the cricket.

﻿Now, it has been revealed Wells billed taxpayers a grand to have a Comcar idle for seven hours while she enjoyed the Australian Open tennis final in January 2023, The Sydney Morning Herald reports.

Minister for Communications and Minister for Sport Anika Wells' taxpayer expenses have been under the microscope. (Alex Ellinghausen)

It has also been reported that Wells claimed $8500 in family travel expenses on flights to Melbourne for the AFL grand final weekends in 2022, 2023 and 2024.

The Communications and Sport Minister, like every federal MP, is allowed to use the public purse on work-related expenses – but in a cost of living crisis, critics say her spending doesn't quite pass the "pub test".

So what exactly are the rules﻿?

Parliamentarians like Wells can use public resources, including taxpayer money, for travel which falls within parliamentary business.

The term parliamentary business﻿ means anything that relates directly to their role.

In Wells' capacity as Sports Minister﻿, she and fellow frontbenchers have argued that attending major sporting events such as the Australian Open, Thredbo for a Paralympics event and the AFL grand final is part of her job.

However, the fact Wells' husband and children have accompanied her on some of these trips may seem like a grey area.

But there is something known as "family reunion travel" that means this falls perfectly within the rules.

Wells ﻿defended her expenses last week, saying "every parliamentarian has family reunion entitlements".

Wells has also spent $8500 on flying to Melbourne for the AFL grand final in 2022, 2023 and 2024. (Instagram/@anikawellsmp)

What are 'family reunion' entitlements?﻿

Under this entitlement, MPs can be joined by their spouse, a nominee or their children at Commonwealth expense if they are travelling within Australia for work and their loved ones are coming to meet them.

Conversely, Wells can use this entitlement to fly back and forth between Canberra and Brisbane.

﻿Between July and September this year, Wells has spent $3056.77 on family travel.

﻿According to the Independent Parliamentary Expenses Authority (IPEA), this travel is covered if it is "facilitating the family life of the parliamentarian's family".

The Minister for Sport flew her family to Thredbo for a Paralympic event. (Nine)

For all other major travel expenses, like the trip to New York, there are certain provisions.

﻿International travel must be approved by a presiding officer or the prime minister.

The budget for each presiding officer is $250,000 per year.﻿

The condition of spending taxpayer money is that every parliamentarian must be prepared to be "personally responsible and accountable" for it.﻿

Every politician's spending is publicly available on the IPEA website.﻿

Wells may have followed the rules, but the opposition has claimed she should have reined in her spending.

﻿"Whether it's New York, whether it's Paris, whether it's Thredbo, these are expenses that would make the royals blush," said Shadow Industry Minister Alex Hawke.

"If she wants to take her family on a ski holiday, she can pay for it herself," Shadow Finance Minister James Paterson added.

title: What are the public holidays during the Christmas and New Year period?
text:
Christmas is approaching, which means businesses around Australia will shut down, and many workers will earn some time off at the end of the year.

There are also several public holidays that fall within a week of each other, meaning Aussies get paid time off, resulting in many taking advantage to go on holidays or spend time with family.

Here are all of the public holidays coming up, and how they differ between states.

READ MORE: Australia Post reveals deadline for mailing Christmas parcels

Millions of Aussies will be treated to several public holidays to end 2025. (iStock)

What are the public holidays over Christmas and New Year's in 2025?

Most states and territories have identical public holidays at the end of this year.

Christmas Day, December 25th is a public holiday all over Australia. This year, it falls on a Thursday.

December 26th, known as Boxing Day or Proclamation Day, is also a public holiday all over the country.

Every state and territory has New Year's Day 2026 as a public holiday. This year it falls on a Thursday, though two regions also have a part-day public holiday the day before on New Year's Eve.

Sydney may be the epicentre of New Year's Eve celebrations, but it doesn't have a public holidat on December 31. (Getty)

What is a 'part-day' public holiday?

In South Australia and the Northern Territory, 7pm to midnight on December 31 is designated as a part-day holiday.

Both also observe the same type of public holiday on Christmas Eve, December 24th, which is on a Wednesday this year.

Anyone working between those hours on a part-day public holiday will be entitled to public holiday rates, which could be up to double time and a half.

Why is December 26th a public holiday?

December 26th, known as Boxing Day, is a public holiday in many Commonwealth countries.

It was traditionally when tradespeople, servants and the poor were presented with gifts﻿, also called "Christmas boxes", which is how the term Boxing Day came into popular use.

The Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race begins on Boxing Day every year. (Getty)

Whilst this purpose has changed, it can be a day of celebration with friends and family at the beach, but other significant events also occur on this day.

It is the start of Boxing Day sales and a busy shopping period, but also marks the beginning of the famous Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race, as well as the Boxing Day cricket test, held annually at the Melbourne Cricket Ground.

title: Queensland family living in a tent says they're not considered homeless
text:
A regional Queensland family leasing a powered tent site at a caravan park has been told it is no longer considered homeless and not eligible for crisis accommodation.

Simone and Steve Owen moved to Bundaberg, about 400 kilometres north of Brisbane, with their two children earlier this year after the lease on the property they rented at Townsville for seven years was not renewed.

Despite applying for "about 100 properties" since January, the couple was unable to secure a home in the town and couch surfed with family and friends until moving to the tent site one month ago.

The family signed a lease at a caravan park one month ago. (ABC News: Johanna Marie)

Mrs Owen said they signed a six-month lease with the caravan park because it was "safer" than camping in public parks.

"We're paying $680 a fortnight to live here," she said.

" It's ridiculously expensive to live on a bit of dirt. "

The family's weekly charge is comparable with the fees for non-permanent visitors at the park.

Mrs Owen said after signing the lease, community housing provider Regional Housing Limited explained that because the agreement was considered "independent living", the family did not qualify for crisis accommodation for people considered homeless.

The family will remain on the social housing register, which has an average wait time of two and a half years.

Mrs Owen said the situation had been particularly difficult on her children, aged 11 and 13.

"As a mum I feel bad for my kids that they're in this situation," she said.

"I just want a roof over my boys' heads … That's all I'm asking for, just tiny bit of help and compassion."

The couple is making the best of the situation for their children. (ABC News: Johanna Marie)

Short-term and emergency housing

A spokesperson from the Department of Housing and Public Works declined to comment on the couple's case for privacy reasons.

In a statement to the ABC, the spokesperson said the department funded community housing providers, including Regional Housing Limited, to support people experiencing or at risk of homelessness.

They said the department had allocated more than $396 million to 91 organisations in the 2025-2026 financial year to provide specialist homelessness services across Queensland, including three in the Bundaberg area.

Queensland's social housing register has reached a record high, with the latest data showing 54,922 people on the waitlist in October.

That figure has grown by about 1,000 since the end of August.

Families make up a large portion of people on the social housing register, with 30,709 active households waiting for a home.

Tom Smith says more needs to be done to help people into homes. (ABC News: Johanna Marie)

Bundaberg has a rental vacancy rate of 1 per cent and according to the Residential Tenancy Authority, a median weekly rent of $560 for a three-bedroom house.

The Queensland Council of Social Services told the ABC in October that rent prices in the town had increased by almost 80 per cent in the past five years.

Member for Bundaberg, Labor's Tom Smith, said the government's partnership with community housing providers was failing people in desperate need of homes.

"There is absolutely no doubt that there's been changes and that we're seeing more and more families, which means more and more children living in tents, living in cars, living in the backyard of a friend's place," he said.

"That's simply not good enough."

Storm season in a tent

On the cusp of the school holidays, Mr and Mrs Owen — who are each on a disability support pension — are bracing for the summer in their polyester-walled makeshift home.

They have already replaced tents and other equipment that was damaged during storms in November.

"Whenever we get rain, we hear it," Mrs Owen said.

"Whenever the wind blows, the tent's moving and we have to constantly lower this [awning] so this doesn't get damaged."

The family expects summer weather to be a challenge. (ABC News: Johanna Marie)

She said they hoped to one day secure social housing but in the meantime would continue applying for private rentals despite feeling overlooked, "discriminated and judged" by real estate agents.

"They look at us and say, 'You're not going to be able to afford that'," she said.

"They talk about the vulnerable Australians — well, that's us, that is my family."

title: Beekeepers pay for imported honey testing to uncover hidden additives
text:
Australian beekeepers have funded an investigation into the authenticity of imported honey on supermarket shelves, with early results showing some imported products are not pure honey.

Honey is regarded as one of the most adulterated foods in the world and can be blended with products such as rice syrup or cane sugar.

Australian beekeepers are concerned Australia's current border testing of imported products is not detecting some forms of adulteration.

Chair of the Australian Honey Bee Industry Council, Jon Lockwood, said the industry was on a mission to modernise Australia's testing standards and work with the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (DAFF).

"We did a broad sweep, we [tested] about 30 [imported honeys] and we found a few honeys that had been pre-packed before they were imported into Australia that showed that they were adulterated," he said.

" We are not on a witch hunt, we are just trying to paint a bit of a picture of what is happening with the honey coming into Australia. "

Beekeepers say shoppers can look for labelled Australian honey to support the local industry. (ABC Midwest Wheatbelt: Jo Prendergast)

Beekeepers contributed their own money to fund the testing which was conducted in laboratories in Germany.

"Our end goal is to show (DAFF) that perhaps some of this honey is slipping through the cracks with their current testing protocol, and that its testing protocol needs to be examined and brought up to the modern day era," Mr Lockwood said.

"DAFF have been really helpful, we've been happy to work with them."

Mr Lockwood said DAFF's testing was "very, very outdated" and did not detect some products honey could be blended with, such as rice syrup.

"It's a very grey area internationally on how to detect a pure honey, and that's what we are trying to investigate with the federal government to see if we can find some better [testing] protocols," he said.

"Any honey should only be produced from the bee, that's what we need to advocate for.

"We are trying to give our Australian beekeepers a level playing field."

Upsetting results

Imported honey is often sold at a cheaper price than Australian-produced honey.

In 2024, Australia imported 9 million kilograms of honey from countries such as China, Argentina, Brazil and India.

Kim Fewster is a fourth-generation beekeeper based near Perth in Western Australia. (ABC Midwest Wheatbelt: Jo Prendergast)

Fourth-generation beekeeper Kim Fewster said it was difficult to compete in supermarkets, and to hear some imported products were not pure honey, as labelled, was distressing.

"It's very upsetting because the consumer doesn't know that the honey is adulterated," he said.

" What I keep saying to everybody is that if you buy honey that is local, if you go and buy your honey from the beekeeper down the road, that is the best honey in the world because you know where it has come from. "

Mr Fewster said consumer confidence in honey labelling was low and the industry was attempting to increase consumer awareness of the benefits of buying local.

"I keep saying to everybody, 'You can buy a good kilo of beautiful West Australian honey for less than a Big Mac meal,'" Mr Fewster said.

Australian honey producers say Australia's honey is some of the best in the world. (ABC Mid West Wheatbelt: Jo Prendergast)

The Australian beekeeping industry has endured some of its most challenging times recently with millions of bees lost to varroa mite and drought reducing honey production in some regions.

Mr Lockwood said the best way for consumers to support the industry was to read a product label.

"The biggest thing they can do for the Australian industry, and ensure their honey is pure and clean, is to ensure it's 100 per cent Australian honey," he said.

"One out of every three mouthfuls of food we consume is directly impacted by honey bees pollinating that crop.

"So by buying Australian honey, we're supporting the beekeeper and therefore food security."

Much of Australia's food production depends on bee pollination. (Supplied: Jeremy Jones)

Testing protocols under review

A DAFF spokesperson said testing was being conducted to compare current assessment protocols.

"Imported honey samples are analysed using internationally accepted standard methods for detecting adulterated honey," they said.

"The department is conducting a pilot survey to assess the authenticity of imported honey samples and compare the department's current border tests with the performance of commercially available analytical tests.

"The results of this survey will inform if further work is required to update our testing capability at the border."

The spokesperson said 5 per cent of consignments were randomly referred for testing under the Imported Food Inspection Scheme.

Between 2020 and 2024 honey products that were tested had an average compliance rate of 97 per cent.

title: Liverpool boss says 'everyone makes mistakes' after win amid Salah spat
text:
Even from the penalty spot, Liverpool managed just fine without Mohamed Salah.

After leaving the Egypt forward in England, Liverpool got a much-needed boost with a 1-0 win over Inter Milan in the Champions League on Wednesday morning (AEDT). Barcelona and Bayern Munich also celebrated comeback wins and Chelsea lost.

With Liverpool's regular penalty taker Salah out of the squad following his public criticism of the club last week, Dominik Szoboszlai stepped up instead to score the 88th-minute penalty which earned a 1-0 win over one of the competition's best-performing teams.

It was all the more valuable coming after a run of one win in six games in all competitions for Arne Slot's under-pressure team, which moved up to eighth in the Champions League table and is now back in contention for a direct spot in the round of 16. Inter dropped to fifth.

Following the win, the attention immediately turned back to Salah's apparent falling out with Slot and whether he would feature at the weekend against Brighton — Liverpool's last fixture before Salah departs to represent Egypt at the African Cup of Nations (AFCON).

"Well, you say everyone makes mistakes in life but the question is should the players also recognise that as well? And should the initiative come from the player or me," Slot said when asked post-match whether he'd like Salah back in his squad.

" There [were] a lot of things being said. That affects the players and the individual as well as he has been so, so influential. "

Salah's long-time teammate Andy Robertson called the club's current predicament "a tough situation".

"For me, he [Salah] is one of the greatest players to play for this club. He has been unbelievable for us. I signed the same window as him and we've been through so many highs and lows," he said.

"Whatever happens, happens internally. We're all together in the changing room, and you could see that today.

"I love playing with Mo Salah and I hope to continue playing with him."

Salah (left) created controversy at the weekend by saying his relationship with Slot (right) has completely broken down. (Getty Images: Molly Darlington)

Liverpool's players thought they had taken the lead with Ibrahima Konate's header in the 31st minute. After a video review that lasted several minutes, it was ruled out for handball as Virgil van Dijk had earlier nodded the ball on to the arm of Hugo Ekitike.

Having taken away a goal from Liverpool, VAR came to the visitors' aid when it spotted that Alessandro Bastoni had tugged Florian Wirtz's shirt in the area, with the midfielder flailing to the ground. Szoboszlai converted the penalty.

Teen sensation continues to star for Bayern

Bayern's 17-year-old midfielder Lennart Karl produced an audacious bit of skill to continue his high-scoring start to life in the Champions League in a 3-1 win over Sporting Lisbon which lifted Bayern to second behind Arsenal.

Karl scored his third goal in four career Champions League games, controlling a pass from Konrad Laimer in mid-air before volleying a shot from a tight angle over two onrushing defenders and past the goalkeeper.

It was part of a 12-minute, three-goal turnaround for Bayern after Joshua Kimmich's own-goal handed Sporting the lead. Serge Gnabry levelled for Bayern when he was left unmarked at a corner in the 65th, before Karl scored Bayern's second in the 69th and defender Jonathan Tah made it 3-1 in the 77th.

Widely viewed as German soccer's best young talent this season, Karl became Bayern's youngest-ever Champions League scorer in October on his first start in the competition.

Late on, Canadian left back Alphonso Davies came off the bench for his first game since March after a serious knee injury.

Yamal sets Champions League record

Headers by Jules Koundé three minutes apart gave Barcelona a 2-1 comeback victory over Eintracht Frankfurt.

Marcus Rashford assisted in the first goal in the 50th and Lamine Yamal with a cross in the second in the 53rd.

Barcelona's Lamine Yamal (left) continued the mesmerising start to his football career with another 'youngest ever' record. (Getty Images: David Ramirez)

The goal took Yamal to 14 career combined goals and assists in the Champions League, breaking a tie with Kylian Mbappe for the most by a player aged under 19, UEFA said.

The visitors had taken the lead with a goal by Ansgar Knauff in a 21st-minute breakaway at the renovated but only partially open Camp Nou stadium.

Son says goodbye to Spurs

Son Heung-min said a belated goodbye to Tottenham as his former club moved up to ninth after beating Slavia Prague 3-0 via an own-goal and two penalties in a game overshadowed by a dispute over moving a rainbow flag showing support for the LGBTQIA+ community.

Julián Alvarez scored for the ninth time in his last nine league-phase appearances to lead Atletico Madrid to a 3-2 come-from-behind win at PSV Eindhoven.

Marseille held on for a 3-2 win over Union Saint-Gilloise, which had two potential equalisers ruled out for narrow offsides on video review.

Folarin Balogun's close-range finish gave Monaco a 1-0 win over Galatasaray. Gelson Martins scored the only goal in Olympiakos' 1-0 win over Kairat Almaty in Kazakhstan.

AP/ABC

title: Wells says 'gut reaction' to travel claims fair but she has 'upheld' rules
text:
Communications Minister Anika Wells has accepted her taxpayer-funded travel claims have prompted a "gut reaction" in people, after a week of scrutiny over her expenses drew attention away from the government's efforts to spruik its world-first social media ban.

Taxpayer-funded flights for Ms Wells' husband to join her at Boxing Day cricket tests and AFL grand finals, bills to hold Comcars for several hours while she attended events, and a more than $100,000 trip to New York for a speech to world leaders on the government's social media ban, have drawn intense scrutiny.

Yesterday, Ms Wells referred her claims for audit by the Independent Parliamentary Expenses Authority, but she has refused the Coalition's demand to step aside until that is resolved.

Ms Wells said she was trying to stay focused on her work.

"Absolutely not, I am the steward of a world-leading social media ban that has incredible cultural and generational change unfurling as of today," she said.

"I am also the communications minister who needs to make sure that taxpayers have confidence in the triple zero system, particularly over the summer."

Wells 'happy' for expense review, but dodges direct questioning

In a hastily arranged press conference outside Kirribilli House this morning to discuss the ban on children and teenagers under 16, the minister instead received a barrage of questions over the details of her travel claims.

Albanese tries to explain the inexplicable defending Wells's ski trip What was meant to be a Sunday interview bookending a remarkable political year became an exercise in explaining the inexplicable.

Asked whether a taxpayer-funded trip where she attended a Labor fundraising event met requirements for travel claims to be for the dominant purpose of parliamentary business, Ms Wells responded that she had referred her travel claims.

"I have three different portfolios and have countless requests to be in different towns and cities to do all different things. I could probably live every day three times over and not get to all the requests," Ms Wells said.

" I always give really thoughtful care in the decisions I make in regard to my program ... I really do do my best. "

Asked whether it was appropriate for a Comcar to wait for eight hours while she attended an event, at a cost of more than $1,000, Ms Wells said she was "happy" for the independent authority to review that claim.

"We are looking at three and a half years of travel," Ms Wells said.

Ms Wells said she was confident she had upheld guidelines for charging taxpayers for travel, but that she was happy for that to be audited "so there is no doubt".

"I absolutely accept those figures prompt a gut reaction in people, I honestly accept that. I agree with everybody that parliamentarians' expenses should be scrutinised," Ms Wells said.

"I have been found to have followed the guidelines so far, but for the absolute avoidance of doubt I am happy for them to have another look."

Ms Wells said the rules were set "at arm's length" by the Independent Parliamentary Expenses Authority.

Pollies charge taxpayers $1.1m for family travel in 12 months Family reunion travel is under scrutiny as new analysis shows federal MPs and senators spent $1.1 million on flying and driving their loved ones to Canberra and around Australia in 12 months.

But the Coalition has said even if the minister has remained within technical guidelines, her travel claims have not met community expectations for how public money is used.

Speaking on Sky News, Shadow Finance Minister James Paterson said it was not enough for the expenses to be audited by the parliament's expense authority, saying the matter should also be referred to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet to determine whether Ms Wells have breached ministerial standards.

"There is a real sense from this government that they had a big election win and can basically get away with anything," Senator Paterson said.

"Including spending $100,000 flying to New York city to speak for six-and-a-half minutes, including having a meal out in Paris at taxpayers' expense that cost $1,000 for food and $750 for alcohol, and including keeping Comcar drivers waiting up to ten hours while you're at a sporting event in a corporate box sipping free champagne.

"I don't think it's sufficient that it has been referred to [the Independent Parliamentary Expenses Authority] only for independent investigation, I think there is a chance the ministerial code of conduct has also been breached."

As scrutiny has spread to other ministers and MPs in other parties, some have also questioned whether the rules should be revisited.

Earlier, while also attempting to market the government's social media ban, Mr Albanese evaded whether he believed the rules for MP expense claims should be tightened.

"I think it's really important that an independent authority be just that, that I don't pre-empt what the independent authority thinks," Mr Albanese said.

title: Cummins's return made official as Aussies name squad for Adelaide
text:
Pat Cummins is set to return for Australia in Adelaide, with the captain named in the squad for the third Ashes Test.

Cummins has been recovering from a back injury and sat out the first two games of the series, but is now all but certain to play in a potentially decisive third game.

Cummins's inclusion is the only change to Australia's squad, which still includes opener Usman Khawaja, who is fighting to regain his position at the top of the order.

Australia's squad for the third Test in Adelaide Pat Cummins (c), Scott Boland, Alex Carey, Brendan Doggett, Cameron Green, Travis Head, Josh Inglis, Usman Khawaja, Marnus Labuschagne, Nathan Lyon, Michael Neser, Steve Smith, Mitchell Starc, Jake Weatherald, Beau Webster

Australia's final team will be confirmed at the toss when the Test begins next Wednesday, December 17.

The Adelaide Test will be Cummins's first outing in any form of cricket since he played a Test match in the West Indies in mid-July.

Cummins's return will heap the pressure on an England squad that is already under fire courtesy of its performances over the first two Test matches.

Cummins has played 19 Ashes Tests over his career and has taken 91 wickets at an average of 24.10. He was the leading wicket-taker in the series last time England toured Australia.

"We feel as though he'll be as best prepared as can be," Australia coach Andrew McDonald told reporters when asked about Cummins on Tuesday.

"He was well ahead of where we thought he'd be at and it did create a real live conversation for [Cummins playing in] Brisbane.

Veteran duo Nathan Lyon (left) and Usman Khawaja (right) could both potentially earn recalls for Adelaide. (Getty Images: Robert Cianflone)

"It was debated a lot leading into that Test match. With that in mind, us seeing him further advanced, we feel he'll be really well placed for the challenges of Adelaide albeit [it's still] a long way off.

"We feel as though the simulation in the nets has got him skill ready. His body's ready to go. Barring anything else happening in the next week, I'd be expecting Pat to be tossing the coin and putting the blazer on."

McDonald also added that Australia is likely to name its "best balanced and available attack" for the Adelaide Test, opening the door for Nathan Lyon's return after being dropped for the second Test.

Loading...

Lyon's potential return as well as Khawaja's likely availability represent massive selection headaches for the Australian camp in the next week.

McDonald indicated that Khawaja could potentially return to the side down the order following the success of the Travis Head-Jake Weatherald partnership at the top of the order.

"The assumption is that [Khawaja] can only open as well. He does have flexibility," he said.

"We like to think that all our batters have the flexibility to be able to perform anywhere in that order."

title: Refugees keep sport of sepak takraw alive and kicking in Bendigo
text:
The hollow tap of a plastic ball reverberates around a stadium on a typically sunny spring Saturday in central Victoria.

Two teams with three players each are darting around either side of what looks like a volleyball court.

But these players are not using their hands, instead kicking, flipping and using their heads to get the ball over the net.

The sport is similar to volleyball except players cannot use their hands. (ABC News: Anna McGuinness)

Among them is Nay Ta Gay Wah who learned to play sepak takraw in a Thai refugee camp when he was 12.

Three decades later, in Bendigo, the sport is still a central part of his life.

"For health, for energy. Happy, you know," Mr Wah said.

Bendigo is now home to an estimated 4,000 Karen people, nearly 20 years since the first family settled in the city.

An ethnic group of South-East Asia, many Karen people have fled conflict and persecution in Myanmar by crossing the border into Thailand.

According to the 2021 census, after English, the Karen language is the second most commonly spoken at home within the Bendigo region.

Players travelled from across Victoria to play at the tournament in Bendigo. (ABC News: Anna McGuinness)

The Karen people are an ethnic group from Myanmar.

Eh Soo organised a sepak takraw tournament in late November which brought together about 50 players from across Victoria, mostly from the Karen and Karenni community.

"We want to maintain this traditional sport we love," Mr Soo said.

"In Australia it's hard to connect sometimes — maybe three or four times a year if we can do this sport.

"It's amazing for young adults to come together and connect."

Tha Htoo travelled from Melbourne to support his team and said it was good to see the new generation of players coming through.

"I think it's good for the next King's Cup. It would be a great opportunity," he said.

The King's Cup is the prestigious sepak takraw world championships held in Thailand.

In July this year, Mr Wah and Mr Soo were among those in green and gold representing Australia on the international stage, bringing home the runner-up trophy in the quad men's event.

The Australian team at the King's Cup Sepak Takraw World Championships in Thailand in July. (Facebook)

"[The sport] means a lot actually, personally to keep active, and my mental health as well," Mr Soo said.

" I would love to welcome the wider community to join in if they want to. Come say 'hi'. "

title: SA prisons remain locked down indefinitely, as home detention officers step off job
text:
Officers monitoring 1,500 offenders on home detention have joined industrial action in South Australia as the union representing correctional officers has voted to indefinitely continue a strike impacting seven prisons.

The Public Service Association union's general secretary in SA, Charlotte Watson, said correction officers voted unanimously to continue industrial action until a fair pay offer was received.

"This is unprecedented in this state, we have never seen a walk out of this kind," she said.

Ms Watson said officers who monitored the ankle bracelets of 1,500 people on home detention also voted to strike for 24 hours.

Correctional officers have been on strike since Monday morning, meaning prisoners are in lockdown. (ABC News: Will Hunter)

"This is an indefinite strike, we are seeing the justice system collapse," she said.

"The premier needs to come down here and fix this mess."

However, government spokesperson Tom Koutsantonis said he had been reassured by the chief executive of correctional services that "they have staff to maintain security over those detainees, and make sure they're monitored accurately".

Ms Watson said sheriffs officers were also expected to join the strike, which would see the state's court system affected.

The union is seeking a 20 per cent pay rise over 18 months, a claim the government has ruled out.

"The union's claim ... is about 13.5 per cent a year, and no other public sector, as a general group have got that," Industrial Affairs Minister Kyam Maher said.

"Most people sitting at home will think that that is far too much for a government to absorb and to keep a balanced budget."

Mr Maher said the government would continue to negotiate in good faith.

But Ms Watson said the government's current offer of between 10.5 per cent and 12.5 per cent was not enough.

"These people have had enough, they are not safe in their workplaces, their pay is not adequate and we cannot continue the way we are," she said.

"Bargaining has been going for 15 months now, it is unacceptable, and we need an outcome."

Ms Watson says correctional officers will strike until a fair pay offer is made by the government. (ABC News: Will Hunter)

The head of South Australia's department of corrections said he was confident the state's prisons would be managed effectively.

Corrections CEO David Brown told ABC Radio Adelaide senior leaders and support staff were working to deliver essential services to people confined to their cells.

He said the strike was affecting services to prisoners, but the department was experienced in operating under emergency conditions after the COVID-19 pandemic.

"We've got strong operational plans in place, we've got a lot of experience of running our institutions under emergency footings," he said.

"There's no doubt it has an impact on services to prisoners, but we have a good plan in place."

title: Houses destroyed as firefighters battle bushfire near St Helens
text:
At least two properties have been lost and hundreds of residents displaced overnight as a bushfire burns near a beachside community on Tasmania's east coast.

Authorities are continuing to battle the blaze between Dianas Basin and Stieglitz, near St Helens, which was upgraded again to emergency level about 9:30am on Wednesday.

It was downgraded to a watch and act alert just after midday on Wednesday.

The bushfire lit up the night sky, as seen from St Helens. (Supplied: Paul Worsteling)

Residents at Parkside, Parnella, Stieglitz and surrounds are urged to monitor conditions.

"The fire is travelling towards Dianas Basin, Flagstaff Hill and surrounds," the alert reads.

"The fire is expected to be difficult to control."

The fire started on Tuesday afternoon and quickly went to emergency level before being downgraded to watch and act overnight, before the danger escalated again on Wednesday morning.

People in the affected areas are urged to stay updated with the latest advice at the TasAlerts website.

ABC listeners and viewers in the St Helens area are expected to experience disruptions to their local radio, digital TV and Radio National services owing to a loss of mains supply power.

Listeners are being advised to tune into the St Marys (102.7FM), Weldborough (97.3FM) or North East Tasmania Mt Barrow (91.7FM) transmitter outputs.

Ned Bramich's photo of the bushfire as seen at 9.43pm December 9, 2025. (Supplied: Ned Bramich)

Tasmania Fire Service incident controller Steve Richardson said firefighters had tried to save the two properties, which could be either residences or shacks.

"They were what we would say is undefendable," he said.

"They were surrounded by dense vegetation, the firefighters put up a valiant attempt to protect those properties, but in the end, it just became too dangerous for them to stay in place."

"There will be some minor structure losses like outbuilding sheds, some water tanks … some caravans were lost in the Diana's Basin area."

Mr Richardson said the key priorities on Wednesday will be in Stieglitz behind Perin Street, where the fire is close to properties, and keeping the edge east of the Tasman Highway.

"We are expecting some fairly erratic winds today that could put pressure on the Tasman Highway," he said.

"Knowing the difficulties that we would face if it crosses and gets into that area where the mountain bike tracks are, and that steep rugged terrain that's beyond, that would be problematic."

About 30 firefighters from the north worked on the fire into the night, using 28 firefighting trucks, three aircraft and two heavy machines, trying to bring it under control.

The bushfire quickly rose to emergency level on Tuesday before being downgraded late in the night. (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

Evacuation centre busy overnight

Running off barely two hours' sleep, Break O'Day Mayor Mick Tucker said it had been a busy night at the evacuation centre at the Break O'Day Community Stadium.

Bushfire threat for Tasmanian coastal communities in north-east On the same day that residents in one Tasmanian community are returning to find if their homes are still standing after a bushfire last week, residents in north-east coastal towns are being threatened by a new out-of-control blaze.

"It would be fair to say that we've had a few 100 people through the door," he said.

"A lot of people stayed overnight, and the Navy Cadets alongside opened up, and they've got people sleeping in there in their accommodation.

"We had people who stayed on the boat ramp at Stieglitz last night as the last port of call.

" It's been amazing the amount of goodwill being shown by people throughout our community, offering their house, their AirBnBs, any accommodation available has been offered... we potentially will need the same, if not more again tonight if the road is closed. "

"And we've been able to put a lot of our elderly and most vulnerable people into some good accommodation overnight, so that's been an absolute blessing in disguise."

For local alerts and advice on what to do before, during and after a bushfire, check ABC Emergency and listen to ABC Radio.

TasNetworks says more than 800 people have been left without power. (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

Mr Tucker said the centre would stay open today, and the council would put on a barbecue for volunteers and people displaced.

Weather conditions on Wednesday are expected to be more favourable for firefighting. (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

The cause of the fires at Dianas Basin and Dolphin Sands are under investigation. (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

Fresh fire crews to join fight

On Wednesday, additional fire crews from the south are joining the effort.

"We've also taken the opportunity to reallocate resources from around the state, especially now they've finished at Dolphin Sands, and are reaching out for additional helicopters to come in from the mainland, including a Black Hawk," Mr Richardson said.

"We're hopeful that that will arrive today as well because that has a very large capacity for water drops."

The bushfire near St Helens seen from space on Tuesday afternoon. (Supplied: NASA/MODIS)

Mr Richardson said he expected another challenging day ahead and said crews would be staggered.

"But we need to bring others in later in the day so they can work through till late tonight, because otherwise it's just too long a day and then fatigue sets in and it's unsafe for our firefighters," he said.

Only days ago, 19 homes were destroyed in a fire further down the coast at Dolphin Sands — the most lost since the 2013 Dunalley blaze.

Hundreds without power, powerlines damaged

TasNetworks said more than 800 people have been left without power in the area around Stieglitz.

"At this stage, safely accessing our assets to assess any damage has been the issue," TasNetworks spokesperson Aaron Vlahov said.

"We'll be working very closely with Tasmania Fire Service to get safe access as soon as possible, only then can we fully assess the situation and get an estimate of time for restoration for power."

title: Spurs under fire after moving rainbow flag for Champions League clash
text:
A rainbow flag showing support for the LGBTQIA+ community was moved to a new location inside Tottenham's stadium ahead of the club's Champions League match against Slavia Prague following a request from the Czech team, according to Spurs.

The Progress Pride flag is constantly displayed in the north-east corner of Tottenham Hotspur Stadium, close to the area of the ground which hosts away fans.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

For the match against Slavia, which Spurs won 3-0 thanks to an own goal from David Zima and penalties from Mohammed Kudus and Xavi Simons, the flag was situated in the south-west corner of the stadium.

"The flag has been relocated at the request of the visiting team to UEFA on security grounds," Tottenham said prior to the match.

The decision was criticised by Proud Lilywhites, Tottenham's official LGBTQI+ supporters' group, which said Slavia "raised concerns that some of their supporters may damage the flag and cause disorder if it remains in its usual location".

"Let's be honest about what this means," the group said. "The risk here isn't the flag. It's the reaction of a small number of opposition supporters.

"That's disappointing, and it's another reminder of the hostility LGBTQI+ fans still face across European football."

Tottenham reportedly sought to keep the flag in its original place but reluctantly accepted it should move due to safety grounds.

AP

title: NFL team turns to retired grandfather to play quarterback due to injury crisis
text:
The Indianapolis Colts have bolstered their injury-depleted quarterback corps by bringing 44-year-old Philip Rivers out of retirement and signing him to the practice squad, a person with knowledge of the deal has told The Associated Press.

The person spoke to the AP on condition of anonymity because the team had not yet made an official announcement.

The move came less than 24 hours after Colts coach Shane Steichen confirmed Indy's starter, Daniel Jones, would miss the rest of this season after tearing his right Achilles tendon, and backup Riley Leonard injured his right knee during the weekend's loss at Jacksonville.

The Colts' number one quarterback, Daniel Jones, leaves the field on the weekend after tearing his Achilles. (Getty Images: Logan Bowles)

Rivers — who has 10 children and recently became a grandfather — has not taken a snap since finishing his career with a playoff loss following the Colts 2020 season. That was the last time the Colts (8-5) made the post-season.

The eight-time Pro Bowler announced his retirement in January 2021 and has been coaching St Michael High School in Fairhope, Alabama, ever since.

But it is not clear how long it will take Rivers to learn Indy's playbook — or work his way into game shape — as the reeling Colts try to snap a three-game losing streak next weekend at Seattle (10-3).

"Things happen. Wacky stuff has happened in this league. Your depth gets tested, your resolve gets tested as you get thrown into some adversity as a unit, as a coaching staff, as a position group," offensive coordinator Jim Bob Cooter said, declining to take specific questions about Rivers.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"We've been through some fire out there, but our coaching staff's excited to draw a plan up and teach it."

Rivers rejoins a team desperately trying to rebound from its worst stretch of the season, four losses in five games. Indy has fallen out of the race for the AFC's top seed and is tied for second in the AFC South with Houston (8-5), one game behind division leader Jacksonville (9-4).

Rivers ranked among the NFL's career leaders in yards passing with 63,440, 421 touchdown passes, and 12 4,000-yard seasons when he retired.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AP

title: Live: Our experts take your questions on the social media ban
text:
Yes, there are several workarounds that children may use to keep their accounts.

They may use Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) to pretend that they are in other countries.

They may try to alter their appearance to try to trick facial scanning age estimation.

Or, they may have a sibling, parent, or another person over 16 do the facial scan for them, to get past the age checks.

The government has asked technology companies to take "reasonable steps" to stop children under 16 from creating and holding accounts, but acknowledges that some young people will slip through these controls.

Children may also start using other social media (like Lemon8, Yope, Rednote, and Coverstar) that are not on the current list of restricted platforms.

The eSafety Commissioner has already reached out to some companies, asking them to conduct a self-assessment, and to enact restrictions if they fall under the legislation. Over time, more platforms will be added to the restricted list, so more and more companies will need to comply or face significant fines.

title: Tasmanian ministers access $45,000 in free NBL and AFL tickets
text:
Tasmanian government ministers have accessed more than $21,000 worth of free tickets to Tasmania JackJumpers games in the past 12 months, available as part of an agreement with the basketball club.

The details were included in parliament's annual gifts register, which also showed ministers had received more than $24,000 in function and match tickets from the Hawthorn Football Club for games in Tasmania.

The Tasmanian government provides the JackJumpers with $2 million per year as part of a two-year agreement, and Hawthorn with about $4.5 million per year for four annual matches.

The JackJumpers defeated Melbourne United to win the 2024 NBL finals series. (AAP: James Ross)

The original agreement with the JackJumpers gives the government access to 20 general admission tickets and up to 10 corporate hospitality packages per home game.

The register shows various ministers received free corporate box tickets for six consecutive matches covering the end of last season and start of this season, accessing 36 tickets valued at about $365 each.

Spirit of Tasmania operator TT-Line also gifted Transport Minister Kerry Vincent two tickets for the first game valued at $480 each; he is one of TT-Line's two shareholder ministers, and the state-owned TT-Line sponsors the JackJumpers.

An integrity expert believes the inclusion of free tickets in a government sponsorship agreement is something that should be avoided. (Facebook: Tasmania JackJumpers)

Ministers who accessed free corporate tickets in the 12 months include Premier Jeremy Rockliff and Sport Minister Nick Duigan, along with Roger Jaensch, Jo Palmer, Jane Howlett and Felix Ellis.

It was an increase on the previous 12 months, when ministers accessed $15,406 in free JackJumpers tickets.

Centre for Public Integrity director Geoffrey Watson SC said the ability of ministers to access free tickets in this way was "really odd".

"I've never heard of it before," he said.

" I don't like the idea, I think the allocation of funding to sporting clubs should be able to stand or fall on its own. "

Free tickets used to 'promote Tasmania'

The government previously provided $15 million for the construction of a high-performance centre for the JackJumpers, and in 2022 a $250,000 undisclosed election promise resulted in sustained political scrutiny over the potential for conflicts of interest.

In February, the JackJumpers were sold to Queensland-based asset manager Altor Capital.

Tasmanian government ministers have accessed more than $21,000 worth of free tickets to Tasmania JackJumpers games in the past 12 months. (Facebook: Tasmania JackJumpers)

A government spokesperson said the attendances at the matches and other events served a purpose.

"The premier and ministers attend such events to promote Tasmania to a wide range of stakeholders and have discussions accordingly," the spokesperson said.

Government ministers were not the only ones in receipt of free JackJumpers tickets.

Labor leader Josh Willie received three courtside tickets from the club and two corporate tickets from Tassal, while Labor upper house MLC Luke Edmunds also received two corporate tickets from the JackJumpers.

Range of other tickets also gifted

In January, the government announced the extension of its deal with Hawthorn until the end of the 2027 season, at a cost of $9.1 million.

The gifts register shows that four ministers — including Mr Rockliff — were gifted tickets to the Hawthorn president's function at York Park in Launceston for the March 29 match against the GWS Giants.

The ministers disclosed 17 gifted tickets for the function, which Hawthorn describes as offering "gourmet food, drinks, entertainment, and networking with club officials" with "reserved seating and exclusive access".

They also received a combined 27 free tickets for two presidents' functions in June.

It was among a range of tickets declared by ministers for the 12 months to November.

Consultancy firm PinPoint Tasmania provided 21 VIP tickets to ministers for the Taste of Summer festival, valued at $95 each; the event received $7.7 million in government funding through to 2026.

Mr Rockliff declared five VIP tickets to Party in the Paddock, valued at $473, as a gift from event production company Vibestown.

Mr Duigan — the sports minister — received 10 corporate tickets to the V8 Supercars at Symmons Plains, totalling $6,250 in tickets.

Tabcorp gifted Mr Rockliff a $1,400 ticket to the TAB Everest raceday in Sydney on October 18.

Labor leader Josh Willie and Labor upper house MLC Luke Edmunds also received tickets from the JackJumpers. (Facebook: Tasmania JackJumpers)

When asked if Mr Rockliff paid for flights, a government spokesperson responded that the trip to Sydney included official business.

"The premier's official trip to Sydney included important government business and meetings, including with Minister for Industry and Innovation, Tim Ayres, a tour of Allianz Stadium, Everest Day 2025, and a briefing and site visit about the highly successful and transformative Barangaroo development," the spokesperson said.

Tabcorp's chief executive officer is Gillon McLachlan, who signed the deal for Tasmania to enter the AFL when he was chief executive officer of the AFL.

title: Complaint filed over FIFA's 'egregious abuse of power' with Trump award
text:
FIFA president Gianni Infantino's public support for Donald Trump and a peace prize awarded to the US president are the subjects of formal complaints to the global soccer body's ethics investigators.

FairSquare, a London-based human rights nonprofit, said on Tuesday it filed requests for investigations into Infantino's alleged breaches of FIFA's statutory duty to be politically neutral.

FIFA said its ethics committee did not comment on potential ongoing cases, and could not confirm receiving the complaint.

FIFA's ethics code calls for a ban from soccer of up to two years for violating the duty of neutrality, though it is unclear if the case will be taken up.

Infantino and Trump take a selfie together during the World Cup draw last week. (Getty Images: Emilee Chinn)

The FIFA-appointed current ethics investigators and judges are seen by some observers to operate with less independence than their predecessors a decade ago when then-president Sepp Blatter was removed from office.

Infantino has expressed views this year backing Trump and his policies, including suggesting the US president deserved to get the Nobel Peace Prize, which he did not win.

The FIFA leader also has closely aligned soccer with the United States government ahead of the men's 2026 World Cup being co-hosted with Canada and Mexico. The tournament should earn more than $US10 billion for FIFA.

Political leaders of all three co-hosts joined Infantino on stage to begin the World Cup tournament draw last Friday in Washington after Trump got the inaugural FIFA Peace Prize.

Trump says he has real Club World Cup trophy US President Donald Trump says the Club World Cup trophy remains in the Oval Office despite Chelsea winning the competition over the weekend.

"The award of a prize of this nature to a sitting political leader is in and of itself a clear breach of FIFA's duty of neutrality," FairSquare said in an eight-page complaint.

FIFA has not specified how Infantino created the peace prize last month, though people familiar with the process in private conversations said they learned about it through media reports.

"If Mr Infantino acted unilaterally and without any statutory authority this should be considered an egregious abuse of power," FairSquare said.

FairSquare has previously challenged FIFA over the human rights record of Saudi Arabia, the 2034 World Cup host; the influence of the kingdom's oil company Aramco which is a highest-tier World Cup sponsor; FIFA governance standards; and FIFA's slow-moving investigation into possible statutes breaches relating to teams from Israeli settlements playing in the national soccer league.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AP

title: How medicinal cannabis clinics target vulnerable Australians
text:
Hannah Wilson says it was shockingly easy to obtain a medicinal cannabis prescription, despite her history of schizophrenic psychosis.

In her late teens, Ms Wilson asked her doctor for a medicinal cannabis prescription to help manage her depression and anxiety.

Ms Wilson said her doctor wrote her prescription with very few questions asked, and no questions around her experiences with psychosis and alcohol addiction.

The now 23-year-old said she decided to quit medicinal cannabis after a few doses, but had been bombarded with online advertisements ever since.

"It's just in your face," Ms Wilson said.

"I haven't interacted with any drug, alcohol, cannabis content, but it still comes up all the time on Instagram and it's frustrating."

Ms Wilson said medicinal cannabis could be beneficial in some cases for those with a genuine medical need.

However, she said she was concerned how these advertisements targeted at-risk people like her who were attempting to stay substance-free.

Carmen Lim says these businesses are profiting from vulnerable young people. (ABC Radio Brisbane: Kenji Sato)

Exploiting a legal loophole

It is illegal to advertise medicinal cannabis products in Australia, but University of Queensland biostatistician Carmen Lim says the practice is rife and growing rapidly.

The public health researcher said Australian clinics were using increasingly aggressive marketing tactics to target vulnerable young people like Ms Wilson.

She said this included using targeted social media ads, memes, Black Friday sales and online competitions and giveaways designed for young audiences.

Dr Lim said the companies used demographic data and third-party cookies to target their advertisements.

Dr Lim said the clinics used cryptic language and abstracted representations of cannabis leaves in an attempt to circumvent advertising laws.

She said these advertisements were becoming more brazen and more numerous, with Australia's regulators struggling to keep up.

Dr Lim said some advertisements skirted a legal grey area, while others were unambiguously illegal.

"The cannabis industry is super lucrative, so it doesn't make sense to fine them a few thousand dollars and let them get away with it," Dr Lim said.

" I think we should find a way to take them down, because more young people are being affected. "

Dr Lim said medicinal cannabis was justified in some instances, but she was concerned prescriptions were largely being issued without a valid medical reason.

She said this was of particular concern when clinics advertised "discrete" and "no awkward questions" services.

Dr Lim said this could signal to customers that the clinic was willing to issue prescriptions with few questions asked, based on self-diagnosis of symptoms.

A Therapeutic Goods Administration spokesperson said reports of unlawful advertising were subject to robust assessment and investigation.

"Advertisements for therapeutic goods must comply with the requirements in the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989," the spokesperson said.

"Suspected breaches of advertising requirements can be reported via the TGA's online portal."

title: Australia social media ban LIVE updates: PM lauds decision as children under 16 barred from social media in world-first; Wells says more than 200,000 TikTok accounts deactivated
text:
It was May 2024 when Nova 96.9 host Michael ‘Wippa’ Wipfli launched 36 Months with Rob Galluzzo, founder of production company Finch.

The campaign was named for the 36 months between ages 13 to 16, which researchers say is a critical phase of psychological development for children.

Michael ‘Wippa’ Wipfli at a press conference in Canberra in November, when the law passed. Credit: Alex Ellinghausen

“Imagine a product, let’s say a shampoo, which, when used by children, caused half of them to become depressed, to self-harm, to develop an eating disorder, or to become suicidal,” Wipfli wrote for this masthead in June 2024.

“It would be ripped from the shelves, the owners locked away with blood on their hands. I wish I could say I’m exaggerating, but the harsh reality is that children under 16 are not yet ready to navigate social media safely.”

The federal government then announced in September 2024 that it planned to limit teens’ use of platforms such as Instagram, TikTok and Facebook. In November 2024, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese confirmed children under 16 would be banned from social media, and the Online Safety Amendment (Social Media Minimum Age) Act 2024 was given royal assent on December 10, 2024, exactly a year before its implementation.

Loading

“Today, December 10, 2025, is now marked in history as the day the law changed after the Australian government chose the wellbeing of teenagers first,” Wipfli said today to applause and cheers in a press conference at Kirribilli House in Sydney.

“It’s an important day. They chose to put the wellbeing of Australian families first, and the Australian government has shown the world that it’s OK to say to big tech, ‘Stop, this isn’t working, and we can do better for our kids.’

“We led a campaign with one simple aim: to delay the age kids could become a citizen of a social media platform from 13 to 16. Just 36 months. That’s all we wanted. A chance for kids to get to know themselves before the world does.”

title: Locksley lights up new rare earths trend in California
text:
Locksley Resources has deployed ultra-high-resolution geophysics at its Mojave project in California to uncover a brand new rare earths trend just metres from its El Campo prospect.

Flying at just 35 metres above ground with ultra-tight 40-metre line spacing, the heli-survey has peeled back decades of low-resolution legacy data to reveal a much crisper geological picture.

Locksley Resources’ new geophysical survey has unearthed a parallel thorium trend to its El Campo rare earths project and next to MP Materials’ massive Mountain Pass mine.

At the heart of the story is the discovery of two thorium anomalies within Locksley’s claims. The first is a well-defined target in the company’s Northern blocks, marked by distinctive weathering that follows local drainage. It also lines up with a broad, diffuse magnetic response, potentially pointing to altered rocks or changes in lithology.

However, it’s the second anomalous thorium zone that has raised more than a few eyebrows. This fresh target appears to sit just 700 metres to the east and parallel to Locksley’s existing high-grade El Campo prospect. Parallel systems can often multiply project scale quickly if the geology stacks up.
